<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 278, 170, 293]]<|/det|>
## PHYSICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 297, 393, 313]]<|/det|>
Paper 2 AS Level Structured Questions  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 338, 415, 354]]<|/det|>
Candidates answer on the Question Paper.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 359, 368, 374]]<|/det|>
No Additional Materials are required.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 390, 386, 407]]<|/det|>
## READ THESE INSTRUCTIONS FIRST  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 416, 719, 490]]<|/det|>
Write your Centre number, candidate number and name on all the work you hand in. Write in dark blue or black pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs. Do not use staples, paper clips, glue or correction fluid. DO NOT WRITE IN ANY BARCODES.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 500, 255, 516]]<|/det|>
Answer all questions.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 526, 769, 558]]<|/det|>
Electronic calculators may be used. You may lose marks if you do not show your working or if you do not use appropriate units.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 567, 760, 597]]<|/det|>
At the end of the examination, fasten all your work securely together. The number of marks is given in brackets [ ] at the end of each question or part question.

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[87, 73, 126, 88]]<|/det|>
## Data  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 102, 668, 560]]<|/det|>
speed of light in free space \(c = 3.00\times 10^{8}\mathrm{m s}^{- 1}\) permeability of free space \(\mu_{0} = 4\pi \times 10^{- 7}\mathrm{Hm}^{- 1}\) permittivity of free space \(\epsilon_{0} = 8.85\times 10^{- 12}\mathrm{Fm}^{- 1}\) \((\frac{1}{4\pi\epsilon_{0}} = 8.99\times 10^{9}\mathrm{mF}^{- 1})\) elementary charge \(e = 1.60\times 10^{- 19}\mathrm{C}\) the Planck constant \(h = 6.63\times 10^{- 34}\mathrm{Js}\) unified atomic mass unit \(1u = 1.66\times 10^{- 27}\mathrm{kg}\) rest mass of electron \(m_{\mathrm{e}} = 9.11\times 10^{- 31}\mathrm{kg}\) rest mass of proton \(m_{\mathrm{p}} = 1.67\times 10^{- 27}\mathrm{kg}\) molar gas constant \(R = 8.31\mathrm{JK}^{- 1}\mathrm{mol}^{- 1}\) the Avogadro constant \(N_{\mathrm{A}} = 6.02\times 10^{23}\mathrm{mol}^{- 1}\) the Boltzmann constant \(k = 1.38\times 10^{- 23}\mathrm{JK}^{- 1}\) gravitational constant \(G = 6.67\times 10^{- 11}\mathrm{Nm}^{2}\mathrm{kg}^{- 2}\) acceleration of free fall \(g = 9.81\mathrm{m s}^{- 2}\)

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 107, 561, 144]]<|/det|>
\[s = ut + \frac{1}{2} at^{2}\] \[\nu^{2} = u^{2} + 2as\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 163, 527, 180]]<|/det|>
\[W = \rho \Delta V\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[445, 195, 537, 225]]<|/det|>
\[\phi = -\frac{Gm}{r}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[445, 235, 525, 252]]<|/det|>
\[p = \rho gh\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[445, 262, 561, 294]]<|/det|>
\[p = \frac{1}{3}\frac{Nm}{V}\langle c^2\rangle\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[445, 305, 536, 321]]<|/det|>
\[a = -\omega^2 x\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[445, 339, 608, 375]]<|/det|>
\[\nu = \nu_{0}\cos \omega t\] \[\nu = \pm \omega \sqrt{(\chi_{0}^{2} - \chi^{2})}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[445, 380, 537, 415]]<|/det|>
\[f_{0} = \frac{f_{s}V}{\nu\pm\nu_{s}}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[445, 425, 537, 459]]<|/det|>
\[V = \frac{Q}{4\pi\epsilon_{0}r}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[428, 467, 628, 485]]<|/det|>
\[1 / C = 1 / C_{1} + 1 / C_{2} + \ldots\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[445, 500, 596, 518]]<|/det|>
\[C = C_{1} + C_{2} + \ldots\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 528, 527, 555]]<|/det|>
\[W = \frac{1}{2} QV\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[450, 570, 532, 587]]<|/det|>
\[I = A n v q\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 603, 596, 621]]<|/det|>
\[R = R_{1} + R_{2} + \ldots\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[428, 636, 628, 655]]<|/det|>
\[1 / R = 1 / R_{1} + 1 / R_{2} + \ldots\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[430, 668, 520, 700]]<|/det|>
\[V_{\mathrm{H}} = \frac{BI}{ntq}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[445, 715, 561, 732]]<|/det|>
\[x = x_{0}\sin \omega t\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[445, 747, 578, 765]]<|/det|>
\[x = x_{0}\exp (-\lambda t)\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[445, 775, 536, 810]]<|/det|>
\[\lambda = \frac{0.693}{t_{\frac{1}{2}}}\]

The weight of the sphere is \(20\mathrm{N}\). The upthrust acting on the sphere is \(170\mathrm{N}\). The upthrust remains constant as the sphere moves upwards.

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[457, 102, 541, 121]]<|/det|>
\[D = k r^2 \nu^2\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 149, 505, 168]]<|/det|>
The constant \(k\) is equal to \(810 \text{kg} \text{m}^{-3}\).

The ball is thrown with speed \(9.6 \text{m s}^{-1}\) and takes a time of \(0.37 \text{s}\) to reach the ceiling. The ball is then in contact with the ceiling for a further time of \(0.085 \text{s}\) until leaving it with a speed of \(3.8 \text{m s}^{-1}\). The mass of the ball is \(0.056 \text{kg}\). Assume that air resistance is negligible.

Use Fig. 4.2 to

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 304, 920, 369]]<|/det|>
The rod in **(b)** has cross-sectional area \(A\) and is made of metal of Young modulus \(E\). It is now replaced by a new rod of the same original length. The new rod has cross-sectional area \(A/3\) and is made of metal of Young modulus \(2E\). The compression of the new rod obeys Hooke's law.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 380, 920, 399]]<|/det|>
On Fig. 4.2, sketch the variation with \(F\) of the length \(L\) for the new rod from \(F = 0\) to \(F = 90 \text{kN}\).

<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 755, 91]]<|/det|>
State the relationship between the intensity and the amplitude of a wave.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[856, 133, 920, 152]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 164, 146, 183]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 164, 920, 198]]<|/det|>
Microwaves of the same amplitude and wavelength are emitted in phase from two sources P and Q. The sources are arranged as shown in Fig. 5.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[245, 205, 747, 370]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 389, 532, 408]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 5.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 421, 920, 454]]<|/det|>
A microwave detector is moved along a path that is parallel to the line joining P and Q. A series of intensity maxima and intensity minima are detected.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 467, 918, 501]]<|/det|>
When the detector is at a point X, the distance PX is \(1.840 \text{m}\) and the distance QX is \(2.020 \text{m}\). The microwaves have a wavelength of \(6.0 \text{cm}\).
